segments.text: Now, Professor Dease, I would like you to explain to me your interest and how your interest in oceanography developed.

Well, I was a student at the University of Illinois back in the 30s, and I became interested in geology, as in those days most people did, either by being what we now call rock hounds or by paleontology, vertebrate paleontology, but I...

interested in geology through a colleague in collecting minerals from New Jersey around the famous localities of Franklin Furnace and also through contact with the American Museum of Natural History in New York and this is basically why I became interested in geology and with that background I went to the University of Illinois
for no good reason.
I went there to be far away from home.
I thought that was sort of out in Indian country, being born in New Jersey.
But my mother was recently deceased, and my father was just beginning of the Depression years, and things were very difficult financially.
So I hitchhiked out there and reported in.
I presented myself and was accepted.
My brother-in-law had been there at the University of Illinois.
And I went through seven years of school, by the way, at the University of Illinois on a total budget of $400, which is being rather remarkable.
That is about $400 outside help from my family.
The rest I earned my own way all the way through.
But in my junior year, I became under the influence of
two professors there.
One was Francis, Francis Shepherd, and the other was Harold, Harold Wanless.
Harold Wanless, his son now, Harold Wanless, is now a, on the staff across the street at Rosenstiel.
But, Shepherd, at that time, I guess I was just in my senior year then, and he
was beginning his work in marine geology.
You asked why people become interested in oceanography in those days.
I think oceanography was a rich man's hobby in the 30s.
And prior to that, it was people who were yachtsmen and interested in the sea and had the means or connection to pursue these interests.
Well, we can come back to that.
But anyway, Shepard at that time received a applied for and received a grant to study the submarine canyons off the California coast from the Geological Society of America.
And this was a grant for $10,000 from the newly established Penrose Fund.
Penrose was a
mining engineer who made substantial sums of money, I believe, mainly in the copper mines of northern Michigan.
And he left a big question.
As I recall, it was $3.5 million to the, something of that order, to the Geological Society of America and an equal amount to the Philosophical Society of Philadelphia.
And this grant was of unheard of size.
Because most grants before that time had been maybe up to $1,000.
But to have a $10,000 grant was rather unheard of.
It was unique.
That would be 1936, I suppose.
Now, Shepard, with that money, proposed going to Scripps and using an oceanographic vessel, the E.W.
Scripps, for an entire year.
Plus, all the expenses involved in $10,000.
This also would be rather remarkable nowadays, because even as of 10 years ago, the cost of a ship was something like $1 per ton per day.
And now I suppose the cost is something like $2 per ton per day for the use of a ship.
In other words, $10,000 might last you two days.
But in those days, it was programmed to last a year, at least six months usage of a boat, which we in fact essentially got.
six months at sea.
Well anyway, Shepard was a professor at University of Illinois and he was came from a rather wealthy family and he had

became interested in, he had his PhD from Chicago and came to Illinois and he was in structural geology but I guess he went back to Marblehead and became interested in collecting sediments on the shelf off the Atlantic coast and he discovered that they didn't just decrease from coarse to fine as was the classic idea offshore but there was a very random distribution of sediments and
he developed his interest in marine geology.
And he, I think, is properly recognized as the father of oceanography, at least for the U.S. And a good many students all over the country now are his students, or students of his students.
And he wrote his first paper with George Coee, but then with this grant he enlisted
Emory, Kenkel Emory and myself, students at the University of Illinois, to work with him.
Well, in fact, I guess he enlisted Emory.
Emory had just arrived in his junior year from, he had spent two years in school at Texas, and he had gone to the San Diego World's Fair of 1935, and to let you know how
penurious things were in those days.
He came back riding the rods in a railroad train.
When he got as far as Illinois, it became too tired to go any further.
He got off and went to school for that reason.
This is how he chose Illinois, because he was tired of riding that freight train.
But Emory, I think, is the only true genius I've ever known.
And you can describe genius as being 99% work.
He was a really
dedicated and a worker.
And at that time, Shepard was working up what we call the boat sheets of the Coast and Geodetic Survey.
He was contouring the boat sheets.
He was making topographic maps, particularly of the California region, bathymetric maps based upon the USGS contour
sheets.
And Emory was doing this, mainly the basic contouring.
And I got involved in a small way.
But when this grant came through, rather than Shepard really hiring me, I learned about it.
And I went to Shepard.
I guess I was sufficiently aggressive to hunt him out and suggest this myself.
And he accepted the fact that I also should join the project.
And with that,
began my series of sojourns to California with Emory and with Shepard.
And Shepard was remarkable in that he not only accepted us as his students, we became really part of his family.
We both lived in his attic room in his house there in Urbana, Emory and I.
But we began a series of trips to California.
spending a semester at Illinois and a semester in the summer at Scripps.
I guess this first year we, and working on this project, first on this one grand of $10,000, I think this money was spent, well, Emery and I received $30 a month.
We received a dollar a day for our services.
And this involved going back and forth to Scripps, hitchhiking.
We went hitchhiking, or one time I went to Chicago and joined one of these carpools.
And I went all the way to California for $10 in a carpool.
So this is the sort of operation you ran in those days.
Yes?
Did the romance of sea have anything to do with you choosing to work with Professor Shepherd?
Oh, yes, definitely.
The sea was an interesting environment.
It was an environment where the sea only reflected the sky.
We didn't have any idea what was beneath the sea, and they were very rather classical and primitive ideas.
I guess the amount of or the lack of knowledge of the sea was remarkable in those days.
we knew there were submarine canyons.
We knew there was a continental shelf, and we knew there was a continental slope.

We knew nothing, essentially nothing, about the topography or the geomorphology of the deep ocean, and only very primitive information upon the sediments of the continental shelf and the nature of what we now call the shelf break.
The state of knowledge was remarkably primitive.
Did this encourage you to enter the field?
It seems like the field has been an uncertain future for geologists.
Well, not only uncertain, it had no future because there's no demand for something which hasn't been invented yet.
And Shepard did it out of love of the sea.
He was a yachtsman and raised by the sea, and he had this basic lore and love of a New Englander for the sea.
His father was another famous yachtsman.
In the case of Emery and myself, we knew nothing about the sea, but we were intrigued by the mystery of the sea.
But being a marine geologist, the word had been invented.
Even being an oceanographer, it hadn't been invented.
And this was analogous with a person opting to be a poet.
And when you said you were doing oceanography, people said, what's that?

You went to Scripps and there was a, where Scripps Institution now is, there was the only sign on the road going out there that said, public sign, put up the highway department and said, fish lab, pointing out fish lab two miles.
That was the only people in town in La Jolla didn't really realize that this was a marine biologic laboratory or even an oceanographic laboratory.
This was a general state of knowledge.
Well, did you feel any hesitancy about trying this, or were you just young and anxious?
Well, no hesitancies at all, no.
A matter of being young and aggressive and interested.
And besides, there really wasn't much to turn to, because the employment situation was so bad that you really
You didn't have people advising you on careers.
And even at these wages, this at least was a job, was something to do, and something very exciting to do.
But it was just like being a poet.
My other interest when I was a child was from reading books of science, like James Dean's.
I became interested in also in astronomy as a child from reading books by James Jeans and Eddington.
And this was also on a par with, I guess, being a poet.
There were no careers in astronomy.
And so I think the practicality of doing geology perhaps is one reason why I went in that direction.
As far as being an oceanographer or a marine geologist, this was on par with it.
with being a poet nowadays.
I hope being a poet in the future isn't always such a bleak field.
It shouldn't be.
It's very useful.
How would you explain then, for example, let's say Stetson and Shepherd's decision to ply the field separately and on different coasts and yet kind of simultaneously?
Well, this was perhaps fortuitous.
Shepard was a New Englander, and he came to University of Illinois.
And he had visited the West Coast and did this very preliminary work on submarine canyons and became intrigued with the West Coast.
And of course, the submarine canyons were accessible because they come right on to the beach line.
And you could survey them by rowboat, by lead line, and by very, very simple techniques.
of investigating Submarine Canyon.
So I think this is why his thrust was towards the West.
So he became a Californian by adoption.
Stetson, I think, also was, in a sense, an oceanographer as a rich man's hobby.
I'm not sure whether he was very wealthy, but I guess he was reasonably so.
Other examples, of course, of this, of the rich man's hobby, is this is how many people got in.
Columbus, Disneyland, for example, and I think it also applies to Roger Revelle.
But this was more or less the background of early oceanographers.
I mean, going back to Alexander Agassiz and the Albatross in the turn of the century, these people were people of wealth who became interested in the sea.
Was it easier to acquire a vessel in the 30s?
I was amazed that you were able to acquire the scripts for six months with
what seems to be not a great deal of effort.
Now there's a couple of your waiting lists frequently.
Well, the E.W.
Scripps was acquired from Louis Stone, a Hollywood actor, and either purchased or given to Scripps.
The previous history of oceanographic vessels, including the
early vessel scrips that had caught on fire and burned.
And this is also as typical of many, of early oceanography, as many, many, many tragic happenings with oceanographic ships.
The French ship, the Puercoipa, the Carnegie that burnt in the Pacific, the non-magnetic ship and so forth.
But the E.W.
Scripps was acquired from a Hollywood actor at nominal, a very small cost.
I guess it was purchased through the funds of
of Robert Scripps, who was, I guess, the son of Ellen Browning and E.W.
Scripps.
But then, as now, there were no funds to run ships.
You could acquire ships, but you didn't have funds.
The whole budget of Scripps Institution when I was there was $125,000.
Our budget for running our marine geology lab was $50 a year, buying all the equipment, chemicals, glassware.
So Scripps had that ship, and Harold Sverdip had just arrived.
And he wanted to do a serial collection of oceanographic data, but he didn't have the funds to operate the ship.
So Shepard came along with money.
albeit a small amount.
I think it may be the cost of what he put into the, I guess he put in about maybe $6,000 of the $10,000 just for into the operating ship, worth about $1,000 a month for about six months operation.
So that's how that came about.
Now, describe very briefly the shipboard routine that you went through on this early vessel.
Did you, for example, handle all the cooking yourself, or do you have special duties and watches?
Well, we did everything.
The crew consisted of a skipper, an engineer, and one mate deckhand.
In other words, a crew of three.
And I guess we also, on long trips, we had a cook crew of four.
Otherwise, the scientists also acted as technicians.
We stood watches.
We were on the helm, and we stood watches of, I guess, six on, six off, or four on, eight off, or whatever.
And we also operated all the...
the winches, all the equipment, and also did all the chemical work aboard.
We did the analyses for phosphates and nitrates aboard ships.
So the scientific staff, which may have been another four or five people, was not specialized as of today.
We stood all the watches and ran the echo sounder and recorded the soundings.
This was very good.
This made us really, because E.W.
Scripps was a very small ship.
It was 96 feet, and it only had a freeboard of three or four feet.
We really felt close to the sea, and the decks were awash and developed a very intimate relationship to the sea.
It's not as intimate as a scuba diver gets today, but it was a much more intimate relationship than you have aboard modern ships when you're
I mean, being right on the sea and being in the splash and seeing the water is a lot different from being up on a large ship removed from the sea, really, being dry.
What were scripts like when you arrived?
The staff could not have been very large.
No, there was a half a dozen scientists.
Perhaps the most eminent one was the newly arrived
Harold Sverdrup, but really the classical naturalist was Sumner, who worked on evolution problems.
And he was a real classical naturalist.
He was the Carl Hubbs of those days.
Now the naturalist there is Carl Hubbs, as you probably know.
In any scientific laboratory, like at Scripps, which for example, at Scripps,

Just a few years back, I came to Scripps with a, I lived and living in the Ohio, and I arrived at Scripps with a mushroom or a fungus from my yard, and I couldn't find anybody in the whole place who could tell me what it was except for Carl Hubbs, and right away he could tell me the genus and species.
It was Amanita phalloides, which is a very poisonous one, but he was the person you would go to for any
questions of general.
In Illinois, we had Professor Wanless, who was a man of this type, who more or less had very broad general knowledge.
But Scripps was, and before that Sumner was this type of person.
He was a nationalist there, and it was very primitive by modern standards.
Only that one Ritter Hall and Scripps Hall were there.
We had one
one secretary for the entire Scripps Institution, director secretary.
She also, I guess, was business manager, as well as being secretary, and a very small staff.
What were your first interests when you arrived at Scripps?
Towards what did you try to drive your geological training?
We were assistants to Francis Shepard, of course, and our interest was getting to sea on EW scripts as soon as possible.
And to build and design the equipment, we needed to investigate the topography and the submarine canyons and the offshore.
This involved right away in making
making dredges, coring devices, current meters, sediment traps.
The EWS Cripps had a new echo sounder aboard it, one of the early submarine signal flashing light.
It was not a recording echo sounder, but it was the latest thing in echo sounding because part of that you simply had to lower a line with a weight on it, but now they had a sonic echo sounder.
And so we had to get all the equipment together and get it working and even design things.
You couldn't buy things off the shelf.
And so we had to look through literature and see what had been made and make our own and make new ones.
And we also had to do this at a very little expense.
We had to go down and pick up lead in the scrap yard and melt it down and make weights and design our own coring device.
gravity type.
Emery and I designed what was then a new type of coring device.

And also at that time, Shepard invested a substantial amount of his money, which was $1,000, in the abortive Varney-Redwine hydrostatic corer, which was, as you probably will hear something about in these recordings,
did not actually work.
The whole thing collapsed and imploded.
But anyway, this was one of the abortive things was to have these two UCLA students develop this device.
So we were mainly involved in getting the work at sea underway and designing and building equipment with our own hands and with the assistance of one technician there named Carl Johnson.
He was a Scripps technician, and he was very
He would help us, and he had a machine shop, and we would build this equipment.
Yeah, I have some questions I'd like to ask you about the development of your devices.
What was the story behind the failure of the Vorney hydrostatic core?
What was its flaw that caused it not to work?
Well, it was, of course, based upon using the hydrostatic pressure of the sea to drive the piston.
and drive the core barrel.
And the principle is valid.
In any sort of a new development like that, it's a lot more complex than it seems.
It isn't something you develop some weekend or overnight.
And it's quite proper for the first, expectable nowadays, for the first models not to work.

I think Shepard was very impatient about the whole thing, and he is a man who likes devices with more than one electronic tube or transistor, because he was always, he was not mechanically inclined himself, and the Varney-Redwine thing took a long time to, was a fancy piece of equipment, and when it was finally tested, it simply
imploded and we just came back with a frayed bitter end of the cable so it isn't quite clear what happened but it apparently did not withstand the hydrostatic pressures of the ocean.
Well what did you work on beside the 600-pound gravity core?
Did you develop any other devices in this period?
No, I would say that was the only sort of a device which was in any way
new.
We did some experiments with it, and we got involved in the mechanics of coring.
Emory and I wrote a paper about it, but in the Geological Society of America bulletin.
But we developed snappers, but these were not new.
Emory developed a sediment trap, which was a rather new device, and we
designed dredges and learned something about the techniques of dredging and the amount of scope you put out and the proper way to develop a dredge.
But we were developing dredges for collecting rocks, and this was quite new.
There were dredges for collecting biological materials, and you always try to avoid rock with these, but we were going after the rock.
So this was, this developing dredges was, but we didn't really develop anything new in the way of principles, we just put the equipment together.
